events.name: Battle of Megiddo
events.story: Around 1457 BCE, Pharaoh Thutmose III led Egyptian forces to victory over a coalition of Canaanite kings near Megiddo. This is considered the first recorded battle in human history, documented in detailed inscriptions on temple walls.
events.hint-1: This was the first recorded battle in human history.
events.hint-2: It involved Pharaoh Thutmose III and a coalition of Canaanite kings.
events.hint-3: It took place in a location whose name later inspired 'Armageddon'.

events.name: Construction of the Great Pyramids of Giza
events.story: Around 2600 BCE, the Egyptians began constructing the Great Pyramids at Giza during the Fourth Dynasty. Built as tombs for the pharaohs Khufu, Khafre, and Menkaure, these monumental structures became enduring symbols of ancient engineering and power.
events.hint-1: These structures were built as tombs for pharaohs.
events.hint-2: They are one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World.
events.hint-3: You can still see them near modern-day Cairo.

events.name: Code of Hammurabi Inscribed
events.story: Around 1750 BCE, King Hammurabi of Babylon established one of the earliest known sets of written laws. Inscribed on a basalt stele, the Code of Hammurabi outlined legal standards, punishments, and social order in Mesopotamian society.
events.hint-1: This artifact contains one of the earliest written legal codes.
events.hint-2: It was created by a Babylonian king.
events.hint-3: Its motto could be summarized as 'an eye for an eye'.

events.name: The Trojan War
events.story: According to ancient Greek legend, the Trojan War took place around 1200 BCE when Greek forces besieged the city of Troy after Paris of Troy abducted Helen of Sparta. The epic tales of this war were immortalized in Homer's Iliad and Odyssey.
events.hint-1: This legendary conflict inspired Homer's Iliad.
events.hint-2: It was sparked by the abduction of Helen.
events.hint-3: A famous 'wooden horse' played a key role in its end.

events.name: Establishment of the Roman Republic
events.story: In 509 BCE, the Roman people overthrew their last king, Lucius Tarquinius Superbus, ending the Roman monarchy. In its place, they established the Roman Republic — a new system of government led by elected consuls and a senate. This marked the beginning of Rome’s transformation into a dominant power in the ancient world.
events.hint-1: This event ended Rome’s period of kings.
events.hint-2: It introduced a system led by consuls and a senate.
events.hint-3: It laid the foundation for what would become the Roman Empire.

events.name: Construction of the Parthenon
events.story: Between 447 and 432 BCE, the ancient Athenians built the Parthenon atop the Acropolis under the leadership of Pericles. Dedicated to the goddess Athena, the temple symbolized the height of Classical Greek architecture and Athenian power.
events.hint-1: A temple dedicated to the goddess Athena.
events.hint-2: It stands atop a famous hill overlooking Athens.
events.hint-3: Its architecture defines the Classical Greek style.

events.name: Battle of Issus
events.story: In 333 BCE, Alexander the Great faced the Persian king Darius III near the town of Issus in southern Anatolia. Despite being outnumbered, Alexander’s tactical brilliance led to a decisive victory, forcing Darius to flee and marking a major turning point in the conquest of the Persian Empire.
events.hint-1: This battle forced the Persian king Darius III to flee.
events.hint-2: It occurred in southern Anatolia near the Mediterranean coast.
events.hint-3: It was one of Alexander the Great’s most decisive early victories.

events.name: Founding of the Qin Dynasty and the Terracotta Army
events.story: In 221 BCE, Qin Shi Huang unified the warring states and declared himself the First Emperor of China, founding the Qin Dynasty. Near his mausoleum, thousands of clay soldiers—today called the Terracotta Army—were buried to protect him in the afterlife.
events.hint-1: This dynasty unified China for the first time.
events.hint-2: Its emperor began building the Great Wall.
events.hint-3: Thousands of clay soldiers guard his tomb.

events.name: Julius Caesar Crosses the Rubicon
events.story: In 49 BCE, Julius Caesar crossed the Rubicon River with his army, defying the Roman Senate and igniting a civil war. The act became symbolic of making an irreversible decision.
events.hint-1: This act started a Roman civil war.
events.hint-2: It is associated with the phrase 'the die is cast'.
events.hint-3: It involved crossing a small river in northern Italy.

events.name: Assassination of Julius Caesar
events.story: In 44 BCE, Julius Caesar was assassinated by Roman senators led by Brutus and Cassius. The attack took place during a Senate meeting, drastically altering the future of the Roman Republic.
events.hint-1: It happened on the Ides of March.
events.hint-2: The victim was stabbed by political rivals.
events.hint-3: This event paved the way for the Roman Empire.

events.name: Birth of Jesus of Nazareth
events.story: Around 4 BCE, Jesus of Nazareth was born in Bethlehem during the reign of Herod the Great. His life and teachings later became the foundation of Christianity.
events.hint-1: This birth is celebrated on December 25 by many.
events.hint-2: It took place in a town south of Jerusalem.
events.hint-3: It is central to the Christian faith.

events.name: Eruption of Mount Vesuvius and Destruction of Pompeii
events.story: In 79 CE, Mount Vesuvius erupted catastrophically, burying the Roman cities of Pompeii and Herculaneum under ash and pumice. The disaster preserved the towns remarkably well, providing an unparalleled view of Roman daily life.
events.hint-1: A volcanic eruption froze an entire city in time.
events.hint-2: The volcano is located near the Bay of Naples.
events.hint-3: Ash and pumice buried the inhabitants and buildings.

events.name: Construction of the Colosseum
events.story: Completed in 80 CE under Emperor Titus, the Colosseum became Rome’s greatest amphitheater. It hosted gladiatorial games, public spectacles, and massive crowds, symbolizing the engineering might of the Roman Empire.
events.hint-2: It is one of the most famous landmarks in Rome.
events.hint-3: It could hold tens of thousands of spectators.
